title: 111_s660
content: The National Pain Care Policy Act of 2009, also known as the Institute of Medicine Conference on Pain, focuses on pain research, education, and public awareness campaigns for pain management. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will convene a Conference on Pain with the Institute of Medicine to address the recognition and management of pain as a public health issue in the United States. The Conference aims to evaluate pain assessment, diagnosis, and treatment adequacy, identify barriers to appropriate pain care, and focus on specific demographic groups disproportionately affected by pain inadequacies. Gaps in understanding and education exist among employers, patients, healthcare providers, regulators, and payors. Barriers to accessing care at different levels, including specific issues for undertreated populations, physician concerns over regulations, and payment policies, are also present. Additionally, there are gaps in research on pain symptoms and causes. The curr_chunk discusses the establishment of an agenda to improve pain care research, education, and clinical care in the United States. If the Institute of Medicine declines to participate, the Secretary of Health and Human Services may work with another entity. A report on the Conference's findings and recommendations must be submitted to Congress by June 30, 2011, with an authorization of $500,000 for each of fiscal years 2010 and 2011. SEC. 409J. PAIN RESEARCH: An amendment to the Public Health Service Act establishes a new section for pain research at the National Institutes of Health. The Public Health Service Act amendment establishes a new section for pain research at the National Institutes of Health, encouraging the Director of NIH to expand research initiatives through the Pain Consortium. The Consortium is tasked with developing annual recommendations for appropriate pain research initiatives. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, coordinates pain research efforts within the Department of Health and Human Services and other Federal agencies. It consists of voting members, including Federal representatives. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, includes representatives from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Institutes of Health, other relevant agencies within the Department of Health and Human Services, and other Federal agencies involved in pain care research. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, includes representatives from various agencies to support pain care research and treatment. The Committee consists of voting members appointed by the Secretary, including scientists, physicians, and health professionals from different disciplines. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, includes voting members from various disciplines and geographical regions of the United States. It also includes members from practice settings, academia, manufacturers, research settings, and representatives of leading research, advocacy, and service organizations for individuals with pain-related conditions. Nonvoting members may also be included as determined by the Secretary. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, includes voting members from various disciplines and geographical regions of the United States. Nonvoting members may be included as determined by the Secretary. The voting members select a chairperson subject to the approval of the Director of NIH. The Committee meets at least once a year and develops a summary of advances in pain care research supported by Federal agencies. The Interagency Pain Research Coordinating Committee, established by the Secretary, aims to identify gaps in pain research, prevent duplication of efforts among Federal agencies, disseminate information on pain care, and expand partnerships for collaborative research. The Secretary is required to review the necessity of the Committee at least once every 2 years. SEC. 759. PROGRAM FOR EDUCATION AND TRAINING IN PAIN CARE. The Secretary may award grants, agreements, and contracts for programs in pain care education and training to various entities. Priority is given to program implementation. Recipients must include information on pain assessment, treatment, and laws in their programs. The curr_chunk discusses laws, regulations, and policies on controlled substances, interdisciplinary approaches to pain care delivery, barriers to care in underserved populations, and recent developments in pain care provision. Education and training can be provided at health professions schools, residency training programs, and other graduate programs in the health field. The curr_chunk discusses evaluation of pain care programs, peer review groups, and defines pain care as assessment, diagnosis, treatment, or management. The curr_chunk states that "pain care" includes assessment, diagnosis, treatment, or management of acute or chronic pain, with an authorization of $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2010 to 2012. SEC. 249. NATIONAL EDUCATION OUTREACH AND AWARENESS CAMPAIGN ON PAIN MANAGEMENT. A public awareness campaign on pain management is being implemented under the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary is required to establish a national pain care education outreach campaign by June 30, 2010. The campaign aims to educate the public about the importance of pain management, the consequences of untreated pain, treatment options, and the need for prompt assessment and management of pain. The campaign aims to educate the public about the importance of pain management, consequences of untreated pain, treatment options, and the need for prompt assessment and management of pain. Treatment is adjusted as needed, and the role of pain management specialists, availability of pain management-related information, services, and resources are emphasized. Other relevant issues are also considered by the Secretary. The Secretary will consult with various stakeholders in designing and implementing the public awareness campaign. A lead official will be designated to oversee the campaign, and coordination with other agencies and representatives will be ensured. The Secretary will consult with stakeholders to design and implement a public awareness campaign. The campaign will address the special needs of underserved areas and populations, reducing disparities in access to diagnosis and treatment. Grants and contracts may be awarded to assist with campaign development. The Secretary will evaluate the public awareness campaign's effectiveness in educating the general public on specific matters by the end of fiscal year 2012. $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2010, and $4,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2011 and 2012.
